title: snp-hq-accused-boris-like-gagging-democracy
story: Its top official has been singled out after imposing an online ballot in a branch, instead of letting members pick officer bearers in person.National Secretary Angus MacLeod, who is supposed to police the partyrsquos constitution, is said to have disregarded it in Coatbridge, Chryston  Bellshill, causing ision in a seat where the SNP hope to oust a Labour MP at the coming election.The branch, which is already synonymous with bitter internal feuding, is due to hold its annual general meetingon Thursday.According to the SNPrsquos constitution, it is at the AGM that branches elect their convener, secretary and other positions based on a vote of the people attending on the night.:SNP Finance Secretary under pressure to boost funding for filthy GlasgowThe format allows questions to be put to those standing for key roles.However, on Friday, Mr MacLeod ordered a debate-free online ballot to be held before the AGM instead.Besides anger over the reduced scrutiny, there are fears this will deny votes to members not online and to families sharing one email address.In a branch-wide letter, one senior local member likened it to the Prime Minister proroguing parliament, writing: ldquoThis is wrong... I would urge any SNP member to completely reject the results of an illegal online vote.ldquoBy having our constitutional rights removed from our branch without a proper explanation we are having our democratic rights removed. As paying members this is an unacceptable way for any organisation to treat their members.ldquoThis decision sets a very dangerous precedent. One that takes power from the ordinary members of the party. Considering the current situation surrounding our Prime Minister and Brexit there are some parallels that we need to be aware of.The author then cited the parts of the SNP constitution about electing office bearers at AGMs, which say nothing about online ballots.Critics also see the move as favouring a clique of candidates close to the party hierarchy and Coatbridge SNP MSP Fulton MacGregor.These include Mr MacGregorrsquos office worker, North Lanarkshire Councillor Allan Stubbs, who is standing for the convenerrsquos position.Last year, Mr Stubbs admitted in evidence to a civil court that he may once have called a colleague a ldquotwisted bitch at an SNP meeting.One local activist said: ldquoItrsquos outrageous they think they can do this. There are no online ballots in the SNP constitution. No other branch in the country is having this. If you pay your money yoursquore entitled to a vote.Another said: ldquoThe National Secretary has taken away the opportunity to vote on the night and is forcing the branch to vote via an online poll which provides no accountability of the results.ldquoThe branch has no democracy and HQ are determined to rule this like a dictatorship.A Scottish Labour source said: ldquoThis is nothing short of a full-blown civil war inside the SNP.:Stuart Waiton: the Named Person scheme is gone but SNPs authoritarian ethos remainsldquoMembers are accusing the partyrsquos National Secretary of behaving like Boris Johnson. This is not the first time SNP HQ has been lampooned for its dictatorial practices by members.ldquoThe SNP are a mess across Lanarkshire, and thatrsquos one of the reasons Labourrsquos victory in the Thorniewood by-election last week will be the first of many across the region.The SNP said: ldquoThe ballot has been opened up to all  local members - itrsquos odd any democrat would object.Asked which section of the SNP constitution Mr MacLeod was relying on for the online ballot, the party offered no answer.

title: theatre-review-signalman-oran-mor-five-stars
story: The SignalmanOran Mor, GlasgowMary Brennanfive starsOn December th it will be  years since the Tay Rail Bridge disaster, when both the track and a passenger train plunged into the river below. Dundee Rep recently staged Peter Arnottrsquos Tay Bridge, which put persuasive flesh on dead bones. Now Oran Mor premieres what is an equally striking and effective companion piece: a monologue called The Signalman, in which ndash forty years after the tragedy ndash the signalman on duty that night relives events that have haunted him.As the memories flood back ndash not least of having to give evidence at the inquiry ndash McGovernrsquos whole body seems consumed by the storm that found the bridge wanting in resilient strength. He begins to question his every action as that -year old operative, taking us with him from the cosy regularity of his signalbox, out onto the pitch-dark track where he is at the mercy of the elements and his own all-engulfing fears. Every terried stare, every shrinking in on himself, every rising inflection of panic at unseen perils appears innately real and in the moment to McGovern ndash and to us, too. Meanwhile director Ken Alexanderrsquos instincts allow The Signalmanrsquos emotional heft to build towards an ending that makes you want to weep.

title: SKETCH   Come into my web  said the law to the PM
story: ldquoI can only apologise, said Victoria Derbyshire, whose BBC morning show had been interrupted to go live to Little St George Street in Westminster for the verdict. Derbyshire had been told the problem was in the court itself, something to do with the torrential rain outside. No plague of frogs, locusts, or other sign of constitutional tempest  How very British: rain delays play.: Historic defeat for Boris JohnsonFinally, the combined force of tens of thousands swearing at the telly did the trick and the lady was for hearing. The voice was crisp, the language as clear as a summer sky. She was dressed in black, but there was no matching cap, the hanging judgersquos head wear of choice. Things were bad for Boris Johnson, but not that bad.The only adornment on her dress, apart from a microphone, was a jewelled brooch in the shape of a spider. In the most delicate but devastating of ways, the courtrsquos president then proceeded to weave a web of Tungsten, trapping the unwise and unlawful actions of the Government within its strands like so many flies. Blistering statement followed astonishing declaration. The effect on the fundamentals of democracy was extreme. Advice to Her Majesty was unlawful, void and no effect. Parliament has not been postponed. Brutal.The occasion would have been more theatrical had it taken place in an old-fashioned court, with the judges handing down their statement from on high. Alas, the Supreme Court, formally established in , is a modern invention. With its black leather chairs, love of semi-circular seating areas and unremarkable wood, it has an air of the Welsh Assembly about it.: PM breaks his silenceThere was something thoroughly modern, too, about the way the judgment was delivered. It had to be before the cameras so the pictures could be beamed live to devices big and small. Some would have watched on a -inch television others on a smartphone screen. All who sat through the judgment could have been left in no doubt that this is what history being made looks like: mundane and electrying at the same time.But who needs fixtures and fittings to add dignity when you have Brenda Marjorie Hale presiding. The Baroness Hale of Richmondmight look seven stone sopping weight, but appearances have rarely been more deceptive. As the novelist Linda Grant pointed out, the motto on the Baronessrsquos coat of arms is Omnia Feminae Aequissimae - ldquoWomen are equal to everything.Job done, the -year-old Lady Hale encouraged everyone to read the full judgment and the transcript of her summary. Up to that point, TV had been restrained in its coverage, waiting to hear what the judgment was in full and not leaping to half-baked conclusions which it could put out on the news ticker. The occasion demanded restraint, and for a while a relative calm descended.: What happens next But then the cameras had to leave the hushed surroundings of the Supreme Court and head once more into the fray. Back to the melee outside court, to politicians jostling for attention, to protesters shouting the odds, the flag wavers and the placard bearers staking their claims. The white wall of static, so often the background to this debate, was back. How quiet it had been in the court, how dignied, and my, how we will miss it in the days and weeks to come.

title: long-term-future-corncrakes-scotland-increasingly-uncertain
story: But now the long-term term survival of one of Scotlands rarest breeding birds is under increasing threat after this summers annual survey showed another drop in numbers.The shy and elusive corncrake faces a perilous future as habitat loss and changes in farming methods force the species to the edge.A survey of the birds numbers carried out by RSPB Scotland recorded just  calling males, down from  last summer.The new figure is also down by more than  per cent from the high of  males in .The birds have a distinctive call.RSPB Scotland said that persistent low numbers over the last five years show that the red listed species is "struggling to recover".Corncrakes, a brown, speckled bird which grow to be about the size of a blackbird, are a summer migrant to Scotland, flying from central and southern Africa to breed.Related to moorhens, coots and rails, they live on dry land and favour grasslands and heath where tall plants can conceal their nests and eggs.But changes in UK agricultural practices through the th century led to a massive reduction their range and numbers, and by the early s the birds were confined to a few isolated pockets in Scotland, mostly on islands and the North West coast on farms and crofts.:The crisis of the vanishing birds#Schemes were introduced to create corncrake-friendly conditions, including delaying mowing dates and creating corridors of vegetation for the birds and their chicks to move through and take cover in, resulting in a high point in . But since then fewer and fewer corncrakes have been making the journey north each year.The causes behind the birds decline are not fully understood although, though possible explanations may be found in their wintering grounds in the Southern Hemisphere or in their migration routes, as well as climate change and the effect of late springs.But loss of habitat in its breeding grounds across Europe is believed to be the chief cause, leading to efforts to conserve the increasingly rare species.Corncrakes shelter in long grassesWhile numbers of the birds in the Outer Hebrides increased compared with  -- with important gains in North Uist and South Uist -- these were outweighed by declines where in the same period, including overall across the Inner Hebrides.One of the most dramatic declines occurred on Colonsay and Oronsay, where conrcrake numbers halved from  last year to just .On Skye, the population fell from  last year to just  this summer, while on Islay -- another key site -- they dropped from  to .There were none at all counted on the Isle of Mull, where there were two recorded last year.:Chris Packham targets grouse moors after eagles vanish#However, numbers of calling males detected on Orkney showed a slight increase - from  in  to  this year, more than double the number recorded in .Efforts are now underway to help save the species, and RSPB Scotland said that corncrakes were helped largely through partnerships between those who work the land and environmentalists, where farmers and crofters are paid to ensure that there is good habitat for the birds.They said the continuation of such support was "vital to ensure the corncrakersquos survival in Scotland".Numbers have fallen across the countryThe wildle charity is also developing a new project to help secure the future of the birds. Saving Corncrakes through Advocacy, Land management and Educationwas awarded more than pound, by the National Lottery Heritage Fund in August  in development money, ahead of applying for a full grant later this year.If successful, SCALE will focus on three key areas, including advocating for government agri-environment schemes which are better for bioerse wildle including corncrakes supporting crofters and farmers with funding, advice and practical support to farm in corncrake friendly ways and raising local and national awareness of the elusive birds.Chris Bailey, Advisory Manager at RSPB Scotland, said: "The crex crex call of a male corncrake used to be one of the sounds of summer across the UK and itrsquos vital that it is not lost altogether from here.:Gamekeeper who slaughtered wildle avoids jail"Corncrakes are a huge conservation priority in Scotland for RSPB Scotland, and for the Scottish Government under their Bioersity Route Map."This yearrsquos results highlight the essential support agricultural communities on Scottish islands provide to this rare and secretive bird by managing their land in a corncrake friendly way -- they are the stronghold for this species and the support they receive must continue over the long-termwersquore to have a real chance at ensuring corncrakes continue to breed in Scotland every summer."He added: "We hope that our SCALE project will be awarded the full grant to allow us to undertake such work to improve the fortunes of the species in the future."

title: one-four-wealthy-scots-drinking-much-every-week
story: More than one in fourScots living in the wealthiest postcodes exceed the  unit-a-week alcohol limits compared to % in the poorest, with the well-off also the least likely in the population to be non-drinkers.Women in the least deprived areas were also twice as likely as those in the most deprived areas to have hazardous or harmful alcohol consumption - % compared to %.The figures, detailed in the latest annual Scottish Health Survey for , appear at odds with data showing that alcohol-related deaths and hospital admissions are substantially more common among the poorest Scots.However, Dr Eric Carlin, director of Scottish Health Action on Alcohol Problems , said research has repeatedly shown that wealthier people tend to be the heaviest drinkers but are partially insulated by factors such as security, better diet and lower smoking rates.Dr Carlin said: ldquoIf you are in the poorest section of society then you are likely to have a whole load of other stressors and health conditions that make you more vulnerable. If you then drink to a hazardous level, yoursquore more likely to have your health affected.ldquoIf yoursquore affluent, the likelihood is that you have better general health. You probably have better access to healthcare, or better housing, better employment, less stress, and fewer long-term health conditions.As a result, they are more able to sustain, in effect, an lsquounhealthyrsquo lestyle.The household survey questioned around  adults, splitting them into five categories - or quintiles - according to the socioeconomic rating for their address.It found that % of the poorest Scots did not drink compared to % of the wealthiest.Dr Joanne McLean, director of research at the Scottish Centre for Social Research , said it was unclear why.She said: ldquoIt could be a financial thing, or that people in the most deprived areas use coping mechanisms other than alcohol.When all lsquoharmfulrsquo male drinkers were compared, however, men in the most deprived postcodes consumed the most on average -  units a week.Alison Douglas, chief executive of Alcohol Focus Scotland, said: ldquoThis coupled with compounding health issues is why we see rates of alcohol-specic deaths and alcohol-related hospital stays eight times higher in our poorest areas than in our least deprived areas."Robust action needs be taken to reduce the availability of alcohol and signicantly reduce the amount of alcohol marketing that we are all exposed to daily.: Teen drinkers in Scotland at all-time lowDespite reports of young people shunning alcohol, the survey shows that % of over-s are non-drinkers compared to around % of --year-olds.Older Scots who do drink are more likely than any other age group to have consumed alcohol in five of the previous seven days, however.Dr McLean said: ldquoOlder adults, particularly those over  or over , are more likely to drink on more days of the week and to drink less when they do drink.ldquoThey are drinking much more within government guidelines, which are not just about how much you drink but how you drink it.: Alcohol sales in Scotland fall to a record lowThere is evidence that attitudes to binge drinking have changed. For men it is classed as exceeding eight units in a single session - equivalent to four pints of normal strength beer.For women, it is six units, equivalent to three ml glasses of wine.Between  and , the percentage of drinkers who lsquobingedrsquo in the previous week fell from % to % among men and from % to % for women.Dr McLean said: ldquoWe are seeing a decline in how much people are drinking on their heaviest drinking day. Therersquos been quite a signicant fall since ."But the drops happening year to year now are quite gradual.

title: queen-should-resign-part-prorogation-says-msp
story: Green Andy Wightman said the monarch should stand down because she had ordered the unlawful suspension of parliament.The Supreme Court found the Prime Ministerrsquos advice to the Queen had been unlawful because it exceeded his powers by infringing on the rights of parliament.It said that Mr Johnson spoke to Her Majesty at pm on August  to advise her formally of the prorogation plan and that the next day three of her privy counsellors, including Commons leader Jacob Rees-Mogg, went to Balmoral to request the suspension in person.Other privy counsellors called the Royal Commissioners then took her instruction to Westminster to trigger the progation on September .Mr Wightman tweeted: ldquoIt is clear that Prime Minister , Royal Commissionersand Queenall acted unlawfully.ldquoAll should resign.Last week Mr Wightman said the Queen should renounce her claim to the official royal residence in Scotland, the Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh, so it could be used by politicians.The Lothians MSP said it would be ideal for housing a second elected chamber for Holyrood in an independent Scotland.Mr Wightman led a previous legal action that established that the UK could unilaterally revoke Article  and halt Brexit without the consent of the other  EU countries.Nicola Sturgeonrsquos official spokesman said the First Minister had no criticism of the Queen, and the blame lay squarely with Boris Johnson for giving her unlawful advice that she was obliged to follow.Legal experts agree the Queen has no choice but to accept the advice from her Prime Minister, as to reject it would cause a constitutional crisis.

title: andrew-mckie-four-day-week-no-thanks-remember-1970s
story: Wersquove just had a splendid illustration of how a bid to balance work and leisure can lead to carnage, with the Supreme Courtrsquos ruling on Boris Johnsonrsquos attempt to give MPs more holiday in the run-up to the Brexit vote. But no one will pay attention to that, because all the media coverage will be of John McDonnellrsquos speech at the Labour Party conference, where he declared his intention to get everyone on a four-day week within a decade.Or rather, the equivalent, a -hour week:  and a half hours less than the current UK average for full-time jobs. The EUrsquos Working Time Directive caps weekly hours at but the EU average is ., just an hour less than the UK.Itrsquos possible that this policy is just an expansion of the pledge in Labourrsquos last manesto to create four new bank holidays, in line with the general approach of offering everyone whatever theyrsquod like and nothing they donrsquot, without any reference to what it would cost. Jeremy Corbyn and Mr McDonnell were until recently singing the praises of Venezuela, which tried this approach, along with many of Labourrsquos other policies, so thatrsquos perfectly likely.Since Venezuelarsquos official inflation rate increased to ,, per cent between  and  and more than three million people have fled the country as it fell into chaotic despotism, theyrsquove mentioned this Latin American triumph of socialism rather less often, but on everything from confiscating private assets to not bothering to cost spending, it still seems to be their model.Itrsquos a bit odd, though, given that the report the party itself commissioned from Lord Skidelsky, while suggesting that it would be nicepeople earned more for working less, concluded that a cap on working hours would not be ldquorealistic or even desirable. It pointed to France, which tried introducing a -hour week but soon found ldquolegislation was rendered broadly ineffective by an accumulation of exceptions and loopholes.Mr McDonnell says hersquos not planning a cap, however, but to realise his aim through ldquocollective bargaining, ldquolegally binding sectoral agreements and ldquoincreasing statutory leave entitlements. So far, so characteristically dirigiste.I can see why it fits his instincts. What I canrsquot quite see is what the aim is. Cutting the number of inidualsrsquo working hours by slightly more than  per cent might create a lot of extra jobs, I suppose, especiallyschools, hospitals, the emergency services and other public bodies are going to keep to their current schedules. But the UK currently has the highest number of people in employment since records began, and historically minuscule levels of unemployment.We donrsquot have an employment problem, but a productivity one: we produce about  per cent less than the rest of the G and  per cent less than the USA on the basis of GDP per hour worked. And the French experience suggests the cost of living for almost everything bar housingwould rise sharply, which rather brings into question the priority of cutting hours while not raising wages.Anyway, where would those public sector workers and the money to pay them come from  Or will public services just be  per cent understaffed, or open shorter hours  In the private sector, are factories, warehouses, call centres, shops and restaurants expected to employ more people  Are the self-employed and small businesses to be prevented from working The dficulty of answering these questions is one reason for asking why itrsquos any of the governmentrsquos business to dictate how much people work, or to dictate precise terms and conditions ndash beyond those designed to prevent exploitation or ensure workplace safety ndash to businesses.Flexibility for those who want to choose their own hours and balance work and leisure is something the market already provides without government dictat ndash not least in the form of that great bogey of the Left, the zero-hours contract. And contrary to Mr McDonnellrsquos rhetoric, both job satisfaction and feeling they have the right work le balance is higher among zero-hours workers than employees as a whole.But Mr McDonnell would like to impose costs and government restrictions on private business, to create additional costs and restricted public services for the taxpayer, to prevent iniduals from making their own choices, and to let trades unions dictate terms and conditions of employment.We had something of the sort in the early s, in the days of wage councils, the closed shop, widespread nationalisation, currency crises, state-mandated industrial policy, private sector pay caps and government held to ransom by hugely inflationary wage demands and constant industrial action, which was why we were known as ldquothe sick man of Europe. We actually had a three-day week in those days, but we didnrsquot like it much.

title: nicola-love-greta-gets-adults-backs-much
story: Of course, there is more to it. BecauseGreta were to just stand there, clutching a climate change banner and smiling sweetly, I am sure the world would not mind one bit.But she does not do that. Greta uses her  to launch blistering attacks on broken political systems. Instead of meekly asking for change, she demands action. It is the kind of authority we yearn for from our own politicians but, coming from the mouth of a child, makes many deeply uncomfortable.Her most recent speech, an emotionally-charged address at the United Nations  climate action summit, saw her accuse politicians of ldquofailing her generation. ldquoYoung people are starting to understand your betrayal, she warned as she took attendees to task over lagging Paris Agreement progress, something that scientists have warned could have catastrophic consequences. But, at leastreactions from French premier Emmanuel Macron and President Trump are anything to go by, it is obvious that world leaders do not enjoy being scolded by a young girl. "@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Greta Thunberg gets lauded on Twitter after angry glare at Donald Trump","description": "Greta Thunberg gets lauded on Twitter after angry glare at Donald Trump","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media iCZMNWF poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests iCZMNWF.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Thankfully, the most important weapon in Gretarsquos arsenal is that she is not on a mission to be the lovable face of the climate change movement. She does not need to be liked, so long as she is heard. Greta is the antithesis of every societal pressure placed on young girls: be sweet and silent, and do not take up too much space in the world. Her candour and ability to deliver uncomfortable truths really makes her critics squirm, because it limits the ways in which they can undermine her.Case in point: Trump, exhibiting his trademark petulance as he taunted the ldquohappy young girl over her tearful speech, came across like a sleaze on the street telling a woman to ldquocheer up, love. Stay classy, Mr President.But perhaps what is most uncomfortable about Greta is that she throws out everything we thought we knew about the dynamic between adults and children. Older does not always mean wiser. The idea that children should be seen and not heard is dead and buried now, though the notion that elders do not automatically command respect ndash that it must be earned and worked for ndash seems too bitter a pill for some to swallow.As Greta said herself, change is coming, whether we like it or not. If that makes you uncomfortable, well, too bad.

title: book-lovers-offered-originality-choice-new-independent-bookshop
story: A passionate bibliophile and bookseller, he eventually went on to open his own independent shop, Topping  Company, determined that it should offer as wide a range of titles as possible.Now  years on, his family business is about to open its fourth store in a grade-A listed former bank in Edinburgh - and Mr Toppingrsquos vision of literary iety continues, with the store offering customers the chance to browse more than , books.The , sq ft building, designed by William Playfair, the founding father of Edinburghrsquos New Town, will now house impressive tall wooden bookcases with rolling library ladders, an unusual oval arts section and a childrenrsquos department offering striking views over Calton Hill.Mr Toppingrsquos son Hugh, who will run the new bookshop with his sister Cornelia, said he and his family are committed to offering customers a dferent experience to the world of online shopping and ebooks.ldquoWe absolutely believe in the physical book and the printed word, he said. ldquoThe book is a brilliant piece of technology and itrsquos so brilliant that itrsquos remained virtually unchanged.ldquoWe put everything behind that belief in the physical book, so the books people see on our shelves havenrsquot been selected by some creepy algorithm thatrsquos built a profile on you and is just giving you what it thinks yoursquoll buy.ldquoItrsquos just a huge range that gives you a chance to wander round and make selections for yourself and choose books that you maybe wouldnrsquot seeyou were just scrolling through a list.Recent figures suggest that independent bookshops are on the rise, with data from the Booksellers Association showing they increased by  to  last year - bucking the general trend of decline on the high street.Meanwhile, ebooks are losing popularity, with figures last year showing that sales had dropped % since .Toppingrsquos first store opened in Ely Cambridgeshire in , with shops in Bath and St Andrews following soon after.The Edinburgh store will open on Sunday and has already welcomed a wealth of famous authors - including Val McDermid, Ian Rankin, and Salman Rishdie - into its premises to sign copies of their books.Mr Topping said: ldquoEdinburgh is a great book-ish city with so much going on in the literary scene, and wersquove admired it from a distance from St Andrews for a long time.ldquoWersquove always wanted to be part of it and when we came across the property at Blenheim Place, itrsquos just such a brilliant building that we absolutely fell in love with it so we went for it.ldquoItrsquos a beautul Playfair building, yoursquoll walk in the front door and yoursquoll se all of our fantastic wooden bookcases with our rolling library ladders. But what yoursquore seeing is actually only about a third of the bookshop.ldquoMost of the shop is upstairs, so when you go upstairs yoursquoll see all of these dferent rooms which all have a dferent feel to them, with bookcases that have been made to fit the building. Wersquoll also do complimentary tea and coffee for browsers when we can.ldquoWersquore really focused on creating a brilliant experience for browsing and discovering books.All of the books in the Edinburgh store will be hand-picked by the booksellers working at the former RBS site - something Robert Topping has always felt strongly about since his dismissal.His son explained: ldquoMy dad was working with Tim Waterstone in the very early days of Waterstones and then Tim moved on from the company and it was eventually taken over by HMV who instituted a lot of more corporate policies and shted the focus from bookshops that were run by booksellers to central buying and ordering from head office.ldquoHe was ordered to have fewer books on offer in the bookshop and he refused, so they fired him.ldquoOf course, it all actually turned out for the best and thatrsquos what gives us our focus on having the biggest range of books that we possibly can, and ensuring our booksellers are the ones placing the orders.ldquoItrsquos about having all kinds of dferent books and not just big bestsellers.

title: papers-economic-reality-trying-compete-new-media-landscape-harsh-spotlight
story: All publishers are facing enormous challenges, juggling the continuing demands of print with the insatiable appetite of the digital world. Our revenue and markets are plundered by the online providers of free, unregulated and often misleading and inaccurate content.And yes the BBC are also a large part of the problem. Funded lavishly by taxpayers, including a whopping poundm for the barely watched new BBC Scotland channel - where there is no measure of success and no audience targets to hit to prove its worth!Together with Facebook and Google their uncontrolled reach now extends into markets once the preserve of local publishers - costing jobs and closing titles.:The Papers: Why we let a BBC crew film The Herald newsroomWe are not immune and we have been open with staff about the resultant financial pressures. Sadly it is now the norm in the publishing world but as you will see again tonight there is a resilience - a bunker mentally that keeps us going.Thankfully all of those who have departed in the past  months have done so voluntary. In many cases such as our sports reporter Alison McConnell they have opted to go freelance and had the financial cushion of continuing to write paid columns for us. We retain talent but on a reduced cost base.As with almost all industries, we need to continually adapt to new technology and new demands. That means taking advantage of process efficiencies and evaluating the importance and priority of resource.Were fortunate that with fewer photographers available in these constrained times, the modern journalist is now so multiskilled that they can take stills, shoot video and upload to site using only the smartphone in their hand. A letime away from the sacred art of developing film or even inserting an HD card. Its this combination of old and new that allows us to evolve and maintain quality, while enriching what we can offer our audience.As a national newspaper the quality threshold is much higher but that does not stop questions being asked and assessments made. In last weekrsquos show, our brilliant photographer Kirsty was filmed waiting for two hours in the torrential rain with our competitors to capture Prime Minister Theresa May. As an editor thatrsquos a valued picture. As a manager thats not the most effective use of her time, albeit we didnrsquot know the PMs arrival was going to be as delayed.And that in essence is the choices we now make. There is no right or wrong just a matter of balance and understanding of our markets and reader expectations.Similarly, the roles and numbers of those involved in the production process have been streamlined as we have taken advantage of technology and put more emphasis on getting it right first time.:Queen lsquoshould resignrsquo for her part in prorogation, says MSPWould I rather have numerous eyes on the same piece of reporting or fewer eyes on that single article and more reporters producing more content Reporters can now use technology to write their copy straight onto the electronic page, adding their own headline and providing picturesrequired - and filing it to our websites with links to added or associated content. I very much doubt I could have mastered all of that when I set out  years ago but for young journalists being truly multi-media is second nature. An iPad is the new comfort blanket for toddlers!Again, for a national newspaper, there is a higher quality threshold and we still need to ensure all copy is checked at least once for errors and accuracy. The small team work incredibly hard regard casting their eyes over thousands of words every day. Occasionally a typo will slip by and I apologise.That makes for dficult conversations and in that respect, we are no dferent to many other professions. Hopefully, though it will come across clearly that my managers truly care about the people who work for them and show the same empathy, honesty and integrity that is the hallmark of trusted journalism.

title: Rosemary Goring  Our gardens are the frontline of climate change
story: As rookies, my husband and I are feeling our way at this horticultural lark. After  months, wersquove barely reached base camp, yet we canrsquot give up now. The gardens hereabouts are a constant reminder of how much there is to learn. Some of them are as lovely as Sissinghurst or Inverewe, and quite obviously require as much hard work. As a result, when neighbours meet, conversation is more likely to turn to brassicas and box blight than Brexit and the Backstop. Also high on the agenda are butterflies and bees, the absence or superabundance of rain, heat surges, the proleration of wasps, and the effect of all the above on the quality of their compost. If you chance to look up at the sky, someone will guess, to within a degree of accuracy, what the next dayrsquos temperature will be.This must be because, like gardeners everywhere, they are acutely attuned to the weather. Other than farmers, I doubt there is any single group more intensely aware of our climate, and the ways in which it is fast changing. For some of them, the young Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg is like Joan of Arc, fearlessly confronting the forces of destruction, and inspiring all of us to be more vocal, angry and proactive. If you have a garden, you cannot be unaware that when she says ldquochange is coming, whether you like it or not, itrsquos not a prediction for the far future. Change is already here. Indeed, serious gardeners are already taking steps, tree by tree, shrub by shrub, to mitigate or adapt to its impact.This became particularly evident last weekend at a Gardenerrsquos Question Time, run by Borders Organic Gardeners, in St Boswellrsquos village hall. The room was packed with people so experienced they cast Monty Don into the shade. A  of three experts, including this paperrsquos gardening columnist Dave Allan, held their nerve for almost two hours to answer a barrage of questions that ranged from how to deal with snails and slugs , and the best apple trees for a cold spot .Opinion ied on what tree to plant to replace a dying ash, but in answering, the alpine expert Ron McBeath said that all our ash trees will probably be gone within ten years. There would even be spores carrying ash dieback in the village hall where we sat, he told us, making a few of us shuffle our boots. It was an uncomfortable reminder that certain forces are beyond control, some bad situations irreversible. Other, thankfully less devastating, diseases were mentioned, heading northwards in our direction on the warming thermal tide. Above all, as Emma Emmerson, of Woodside Plant Centre near Ancrum remarked, everyone is noticing the ldquocollapsed seasons, and the challenges they present to making a garden grow as it did in the past.Concern in the hall was palpable. Gardeners are in the frontline of climate change, seeing in miniature what is happening in the world at large. The  discussion ranged over what we could do to help wildle and especially birds to thrive ndash cat lovers should lock up their pets ndash but in terms of plants, it would seem that we are approaching uncharted territory. Old certainties are no longer reliable.Sombre though it sounds, it was not an afternoon of gloom ndash quite the reverse. For a start it was a reminder of how much fun it is to grow things and, in the case of vegetables and fruits, to watch them ripen, before falling upon them with kne, fork and spoon. It was also an encouragement, for beginners like me, to get more serious. To learn that, across the UK, more land is covered by gardens than by nature reserves is to understand the humble back yard or allotmentrsquos place in a giant living patchwork. Each of these plots, and not just those abiding by organic principles, stands guard on the ramparts, defending the gate against attack.This mild month, with bees still nose-deep in our flower beds, and hedges quivering with sparrows, finches and tits with owls keeping us awake from the horse chestnut tree outside the window, hedgehogs rootling in the field we call our lawn, and a young woodpecker learning his trade on the telegraph pole by our fence, it becomes abundantly clear that the place you like to think of as your own is in fact shared with thousands of other creatures.That will not be news to those who have gone out of their way to help feed the birds. A recent survey showed that in Britain enough food is served to sustain  million birds every year. Species that were struggling  years ago are now making a comeback, among them goldfinches and nuthatches.Itrsquos a glimmer of hope amid the increasingly apocalyptic language around climate change. As the villagersquos green-fingered army shows, there is nothing egotistical or self-centred about people devoted to the upkeep of their borders and trellises, their fruit trees and raised beds. When Voltaire wrote, ldquoit is our duty to cultivate our garden he was not, for once, being sarcastic. A passionate gardener who, as he grew older, craved the simple le, he understood the deeper meaning to be found in tending your own patch. The upkeep of that little bit of earth results in spiritual well-being as well as a barrowload of juicy carrots. Those of us cheering on crusaders like Thunberg can still raise our own battle standard. It should be planted carefully between the raspberry canes or beside a clematis or, in our case, among the rampant, bee-friendly weeds.

title: chief-policing-parades-not-sustainable
story: Iain Livingstone yesterday told his ruling watchdog too many of his officers were being dragged away from their normal duties this marching season.The chief and onehis deputies, Northern Ireland veteran Will Kerr, also railed against ldquoutterly unacceptable violence against police.Earlier this month six parades ndashRepublican and Loyalist ndash were banned by Glasgow City Council amid concerns over public safety.The rare action came after clashes between rival groups on successive weekends, with officers among those injured.Police Scotland mobilised  officers from across Scotland in Glasgow for one September weekend of marches and counter-protests. That cost more than pound,.Mr Livingstone told the Scottish Police Authority in Falkirk yesterday: ldquoThis has been demanding at an operational level but a strategic level as well.ldquoIs it sustainable  No, it is not. The capability of the single service comes in to bear. One of the officers injured was based in Dunfermline. We are drawing officers from right across the country away from their key role to respond to this.ldquoIn terms of sustainability, it is a signicant challenge. In terms of officer safety, there is a growing trend of attacks. There has been a signicant increase in the west of Scotland in particular. They are up by more than a fth.ldquoThe recent manestation of these marches, walks and protests seems to me to be part of a growing trend where our officers are coming under attack and it is utterly unacceptable. It is not part of the job.Referring to the last weekend in August and the first in September, Deputy Chief Constable Will Kerr said: ldquoThose are officers who are not involved in investigating ndash as we want them to be ndash domestic abuse incidents across the city and tackling drug and traffic offences, and dealing with normal police business.Speaking of the first weekend in September, he said: ldquoSo there are a whole range of opportunity costs which are attendant and added on top of that pound, pure cost of the operation itself.ldquoThat being said, the chief has made it clear that to protect the city of Glasgow and its citizens we will deploy as many police officers as we need to do to make sure the city is both safe and feels safe.ldquoWe have set up an investigation team led by a detective inspector ndashover  detectives are involved in that ndash who are robustly investigating all the offences involved.ldquoWe have made  arrests so far. There will be more arrests over the coming weeks and months.ldquoWe will not accept that sort of behaviour. We certainly wonrsquot accept assaults on our police officers.ldquoOne of those arrests has been for the throwing of the pyrotechnic and one of our officers being injuredby that.Police have also been hurt at football matches, including at Rangers Europa League home game against Feyenoord of the Netherlands. Mr Kerr listed problems: ldquoWe had six officers injured before and during that match.Throwing coins at officers. hitting them in the head and legs. Spitting on officers faces, kicking at their legs, throwing stones, one of which hit an officers in the face, punching officers to the face.ldquoThat is just wholly unacceptable. It cannot be right in  that we have officers deployed to protect their communities subject to that level of violence both at parades and associated protests or at football matches.Mr Kerr urged a sense of perspective. Citing his  years in Belfast policing, he stressed that only a tiny minority were involved in trouble. But he added: ldquoWe do need to have a clear, hard look at ourselves as to whether that is acceptable. We should not be putting officers in that position in the first place.

title: papers-digital-journalism-contributing-bottom-line-herald-ever
story: But that was the position I found myself in on day one when I started as Digital Editor at The Herald in November . Naturally, the filming crew didnrsquot miss a beat, capturing the everyday frustration and the ongoing issues faced by all departments amid a digital transformation.While the transition to a more digital focus for the paper has had its own challenges, as alluded to in the documentary, there have also been a number of positives as part of our digital transformation.There is a perception that the growth of online journalism has resulted in newspapers ldquochasing clicks and impacted the quality of the product, but the reality is that we know exactly what people read and what they want to engage with.:The Papers: Economic reality of trying to compete in new media landscape is under harsh spotlightEvery click on our site is monitored, we can tell what subscribers read, how long they engage for and what stories pick up traction on social media.The simple fact is that we need a ing site that generates income to pay for the high-quality journalism that we strive to produce. Media reflects society and in this digital age, with news consumed quickly, on mobile and through social media, we have tried to change our digital offering to reflect this.Online we continue to publish the same content The Herald is known and loved for, with all print copy going on the website, but we couple it with more analysis on hot topics, breaking stories and pieces that we know our readers want to read.It is this strategy that has seen a signicant growth in The Herald with our unique visitors almost doubling in a year, and . million more articles read online between September  and August .Year on year, The Herald is up byaround  per cent in online readership. Last month more than two million people visited heraldscotland, a record high for the year.The Papers also gives an indication of the challenges faced by the digital desk and the modern-day media overall, with The Herald being one of many papers facing cuts.While there is a perception by some that digital is simply giving content away, the reality is that digital is contributing to the bottom line more than ever before. As part of our strategy, we have focused on growing our readership and our subscribers.:The Papers: Why we let a BBC crew film The Herald newsroomBy doing this we have been able to implement a number of changes to improve our digital offering.The BBC documentary shows a window of time but by carrying out the changes outlined as part of our digital strategy, The Herald has been able to bring in staff and tailor content to our subscribers and growing audience. As part of our overall focus on digital, we have appointed a Head of Audience who oversees all social media, as well as bringing in a number of multimedia reporters both on news and sport.Training has been rolled out to all of our reporters and rather than creating separate digital teams across dferent titles, we have merged to become one digital desk that drives forward both heraldscotland and eveningtimes, providing consistency and more dedicated staff to the Scottish Newsquest sites than ever before.While improving traffic is key, we have never hidden that The Herald sits behind a paywall and more focus has been emphasised on premium content and building on our growing number of subscribers.We have continued to operate behind our subscription model and have seen a signicant uplt in the number of people subscribing to read The Herald since our new premium model was launched.With more readers supporting our journalism we have also added to the site navigation subsection, improved our video player on site, and carried out an in-depth analysis on our newsletters with changes expected soon.Regardless of the changes we make, no newspaper is without criticism, however, we strive to respond to our readers, and it is that transparency and engagement that we have tried to use to build our brand and trust online.While readers may not necessarily agree with an opinion piece or certain story, we have constantly looked to be open with our readers and to give them a deserved insight. And that was also a motivating factor in the decision to open The Heraldoffice to the BBC cameras in the first place.The filming allowed our readers to see behind the looking glass and an insight into le for staff at The Herald and the everyday problems we faced, but what it also showed was the dedication and passion that staff have for the product both in print and online.

title: sainsburys-closing-100-stores-major-business-overhaul
story: The grocer said it expects to close up to  supermarkets,  convenience stores and  Argos branches. But to counteract the closures, theyare to open  new supermarkets,  new convenience stores and put  Argos branches in other Sainsburys.The group said it will shut up to  Argos shops and open around  insteadwithin its supermarkets, while it also plans toclose up to  large supermarkets and as many as  convenience stores.:Sainsburyrsquos sees sales tumble further amid lsquotoughrsquo supermarket environmentBut it also said it willopen around  big stores and some  convenience outlets under the plan, which it insisted will increase its store estate.The five-year plan, being led by chief executive Mike Coupe, is set to cut costs by around pound million over the next five years and comes after the failure of its ill-fated pound. billion takeover tilt for rival Asda.Sainsburyrsquos also revealed narrowed sales declines in its second quarter but warned over a pound million hit to underlying half-year profits.It blamed the interim profits warning on the impact of cost-cutting,with weather and higher marketing costs also taking their toll, though it stuck by full-year forecasts.Sainsburyrsquos also announced its financial services arm would stop new mortgage lending ldquoimmediately as part of its five-year plan.It comes amid reports the groupis looking to sell off its mortgage book, following rival Tescorsquos recent move to offload its home lending business.Details of the plans came as Sainsburyrsquos announced a .% fall in like-for-like sales, excluding fuel, overits second quarter to September .This marked an improvement on the .% fall seen in the previous three months.:Asda and Sainsburys shamed in Scottish burger surveySainsburyrsquos said like-for-like grocery sales rose by .% in the second quarter, but this was offset by a % drop in general merchandise sales ndash which includes the Argos business.Mr Coupe said: ldquoSales momentum was stronger in all areas and we further improved our performance relative to our competitors, particularly in grocery.ldquoArgos continued to grow market share in key categories, but sales were impacted by reduced promotional activity and the timing of new product releases in gaming and toys.

title: government-must-intervene-thomas-cook-german-subsidiary-saved
story: The German government has pledged to offerCondor a six-monthloan of poundm, subject to the approval of the European Commission in Brussels,to continue to operate.Thousands of UK workers have lost their jobs and face a battle to receive any redundancy pay after Thomas Cook went out of business on Monday. The UK government declined the request of a poundm bailout, attracting criticism from opposition parties."This step, under the current situation, is the best for our clients, our business partners and for us. This way, we can be fully independent from the Thomas Cook Group plc and gain more security for our future," a Condor statement read.German economics minister Peter Altmaier said "the problems of Condor in Germany are not homemade, and insisted it was a "profitable company and therefore our decision was based on economic factors, not on political criteria".:Thomas Cook -Heres how stranded holidaymakers will be refundedBrian Strutton, general secretary of the British Airline Pilots Associationsaid: "Good luck to the Condor staff and customers, but with UK holidaymakers stranded and , staff out of a job, the Thomas Cook directors need to explain why the UK airline had to be closed but the German one was allowed to continue to operate."How was it funded, because it seems there is nothing left in the coffers for UK staff "And why couldnt the UK government give the same kind of bridging support as the German government when it was well known that Thomas Cook had a Chinese buyer lined up  Its a national scandal."Manuel Cortes, general secretary of the Transport Salaried Staffs Association said: "Unlike our PM, the German government doesnt for one second think that using public money to save jobs is a moral hazard." Johnson should get rid of his undergraduate economic dogma and live, like the German government, in the real world."The problem isnt one of a moral hazard, its the immorality of his Government which won"t even lt its little finger to save , jobs."The British assets of Thomas Cook must be taken into public ownership and just as the Germans have done, the company can rise back from its ashes.:One in ten customers hit by Thomas Cook collapsehome"If government intervention is good for the Germans, it should also be good for us too."Richard Moriarty, chief executive of the UK Civil Aviation Authority, said % of people were being flown home on the original date of departure at the end of their holiday."We have now operated over  flights in the first two days of this operation, ing almost , people to the UK."I would like those remaining on holiday to enjoy the rest of their stay because we aim to also fly you home on the day when you were originally booked to fly with Thomas Cook, or very shortly thereafter."This remains a highly complex operation and I would like to thank holidaymakers for their patience as some inconvenience and disruption is likely."Id also like to stress my thanks to the UK airline industry and our partners which have lent us incredible support for what is the UKs largest ever peacetime repatriation."

title: food waste really can power cars like in the 1980s back to the future movies
story: Just as Marty McFly and the Doc discovered in Back to the Future, our food waste can be transformed into a sustainable fuel to power future energy needs.So environmental organisation Zero Waste Scotland is using this year’s Recycle Weekto raise awareness of the potential energy that can be captured by simply placing peelings, egg shells, tea bags and any uneaten produce in household food recycling caddies.The time travelling DeLorean used in the classic s movies was modied to run on food waste – and the technology now exists to use it today to power vehicles, heat our homes and grow more food.Estimates from Zero Waste Scotland reveal that , tonnes of global warming CO equivalent gas would be saved from entering the environmenteveryone in Scotland with access to a food caddy recycled their tea bags. Disposing this total of  tonnes of material properly would be the equivalent of removing , cars off UK roads every year.When sent to landfill, food waste releases methane, a dangerous greenhouse gas many times more potent than carbon dioxide in the short term.By successfully capturing food waste it can be converted into sustainable energy, instead of being sent to landfill or incineration. The resulting material can also be used as a fertiliser for soil to help grow more food, more sustainably. Iain Gulland, chief executive of Zero Waste Scotland, said: “It wasn’t just fantasy when the Doc and Marty were discovering how they could power the DeLorean to time travel – they hit upon an idea that over  years later could make a signicant dference in how we combat the climate emergency.“Time is running out as we look to tackle the climate emergency. “The good news is that inedible food waste has huge potential as its energy can be used to make sustainable fuel and we can harness this by simply using our food recycling caddy. “You could provide enough power to watch the entire Back to the Future trilogy from the food held in nearly two and a half food recycling caddies.”Around  per cent of the , tonnes of food waste produced by households in Scotland every year is unavoidable. title: four fifths of our carbon footprint is down to our consumption habit
story: Businesses that don#t act now to meet growing public pressure to tackle the global climate emergency risk being left behind.That’s the warning from Zero Waste Scotland which says organisations must do more and examine how they produce, consume and dispose of everyday items just to stay in the race – and urges them to embrace the circular economy.Zero Waste Scotland stresses firms achieving a more sustainable way of working would deliver huge results in cutting Scotland’s carbon footprint. This is because four fths of Scotland’s carbon footprint is generated through the heat and energy required to grow, make, process, transport and provide materials that are often tossed aside at the end of their le.Only by considering how to make products with less reliance on raw materials, and by remaking items at the end of their original le into goods that can be used time and again, will businesses be able to signicantly reduce global emissions.Iain Gulland, chief executive of Zero Waste Scotland, who launched the organisation’s corporate plan before an auduence of business leaders last week, said: “We must radically change the way we think about and consume our goods and materials, and we must do that now.” “Too many businesses assume that reducing the cost to the planet means increasing costs for them. “But as we have and will continue to make clear, the opportunities are plentul, with massive savings to be made. “The current way of working cannot continue in the years ahead and successfully adopting a circular economy approach is the only long-term option.”Everything has value and in a circular economy nothing should be wasted. In simple terms, it can be explained as ‘make, use, remake’ as opposed to ‘make, use, dispose’. The ultimate goal is to maintain and improve our quality of le, while simultaneously reducing our material consumption and, by extension, our impact on the planet.Mr Gulland added: “Many Scottish firms are already leading the way, with our help, changing how they design and trade goods to keep materials in use for as long as possible to maximise their value. “Successful circular economy enterprises range from refurbishing computers and upcycling furniture to producing sustainable animal feed using waste generated by our world-famous whisky industry.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Felicitasis just one of the many children supported by Marys Meals."   is just one of the many children supported by Marys Meals."  Throw a Porridge Party for Mary’s MealsviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"A body recovered near Boddam is believed to be that of Ruairidh Sandison"  A body recovered from the coast near Boddam is thought to be that of missing man Ruairidh Sandison. viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Zero Waste Scotland estimates that the circular economy would save Scottish businesses collectively at least £ billion every year through benefits including the creation of longer-lasting relationships with customers, as firms switch from a model centred on simply selling products to providing products as services. Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham said: “We should not underestimate our achievements to date in tackling climate change – we have already almost halved emissions since . “We cannot, however, be complacent. More action is needed to respond to the global climate emergency and show Scotland as the responsible, progressive, and ambitious country that it is.”

title: join in the great scottish squirrel survey this week
story: People are being encouraged to look out for squirrels # and record their sightings # in support of the Saving Scotland#s Red Squirrels project.The Great Scottish Squirrel Survey takes place this week until Sunday, September .During this week – which coincides with National Red Squirrel Week – the public is being encouraged to spend some time exploring the outdoors while keeping a lookout for both red and grey squirrels. They are then being asked to report where and when they saw them on the Saving Scotland’s Red Squirrels websitescottishsquirrels.org.uk.Saving Scotland’s Red Squirrels is a partnership project led by the Scottish Wildle Trust that is working to protect red squirrels where they are most under threat from the spread of non-native grey squirrels. Squirrel sightings received from the public help the project understand how red and grey squirrel populations are changing over time and decide where to focus conservation efforts.Prject manager Dr Mel Tonkin said: “We monitor squirrel populations throughout the year, and in  we received an incredible  squirrel sightings from members of the public.“This year, thanks to support from National Lottery players, we’re trying something a bit dferent.“By going out and looking for squirrels during the Great Scottish Squirrel Survey people can help us create a more detailed snapshot of the current situation on the ground.”Autumn is an ideal time of year for squirrel-watching. With leaves falling they can be easier to spot as they move through the treetops, foraging for the autumn harvest of seeds, nuts and berries. They will also be spending more time on the ground, building up stores of food in preparation for the colder months ahead.Mel added: “During the survey week you could visit a well-known squirrel stomping ground to help us keep our records up-to-date. data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Jon Marshall, Zero Waste Scotlands recycling sector manager, and chief executive Iain Gulland want recycled food waste to be used to power vehicles, just like the DeLorean car in the movie Back to the Future. "  "  Food waste really can power cars like in the s’ Back to the Future movies viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"“Or,you’re feeling adventurous, you could visit a woodland where few sightings have been recorded before. “The more information we receive from the public, the better our understanding of Scotland’s squirrel populations will be.” Gordon Buchanan, wildle filmmaker and Scottish Wildle Trust ambassador, said: “The red squirrel is an iconic Scottish species. “Thanks to conservation efforts their populations are beginning to stabilise, but their future is still under threat. “Taking part in the Great Scottish Squirrel Survey is a really simple way you can help.”The results of the Great Scottish Squirrel Survey will be published later this year. Each sighting is veried by a conservation officer before being added to the project’s sightings map and the official Scottish Squirrel Database.More information can be found scottishsquirrels.org.uk great-scottish-squirrel-survey.

title: residents urged to support recycle week
story: Aberdeenshire Council is encouraging residents to put waste in the appropriate bins in Recycle Week, which runs from Monday, September , until Sunday, September .More than % of the waste produced in the region could be recycled using existing services. However, the current figure stands at around %. In addition to benefiting the environment, recycling is also much cheaper than landfill.Throughout the week-long campaign, the council is helping residents to recycle more.During the initiative, the local authority’s community waste officers are hosting information sessions at ious locations.They are Tuesday, September  - Banchory Library, am-noon Morrison’s supermarket, Peterhead, am-pm Wednesday, September  - Fly Cup Catering coffee shop, Inverurie, am-pm Thursday, September  - Alford Library, am-pm Friday, September  - Community Coffee Shop at Kemnay Village Hall, .-.am.Residents can drop in and ask questions, learn about all forms of recycling, and find out what happens to their recycling once it has been collected.New stickers are also being placed on the blue-lidded recycling bins throughout September. The labels specy what can be recycled at kerbside and give details of where more information can be found.Crews will aim to cover all recycling bins by the end of the month, but stickers will also be available for residents at household recycling centres .More information about recycling can be found on the council’s website, from checking recycling bin day to an A-Z recycling guide and what happens to the materials afterwards.Councillor Peter Argyle, chair of the infrastructure services committee, said: “Recycle Week is a great opportunity for householders to make a positive contribution to Aberdeenshire’s recycling efforts. “We hope the information provided during the week will encourage residents to make a push towards increased recycling rates.”For a complete guide on the materials that can be recycled in Aberdeenshire, see the A-Z guide at http:bit.ly AshireAZ.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Guide Dogs are fundraising throughout October to fund the cost of training seven puppies, like six-week-old Goldie." Leave the lights onVehicles parking on a road where the speed limit is more than mph, facing away from the traffic or outside of a designated parking area should technically have their side lights on overnight to help prevent collisions.ShutterstockotherBuy a Photo. Check all mirrorsDrivers and passengers need to check all of their mirrors before exiting a parked vehicle as it is always the responsibility of occupants to ensure opening doors will not impede passing pedestrians, cyclists or other vehicles.ShutterstockotherBuy a Photo. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. title: doors open days events to be held
story: This Saturday and Sunday will see Orkney#s biggest ever Doors Open Days event.Doors Open Days is Scotland#s largest free cultural festival, celebrating the built environment and giving free access to around one thousand venues across Scotland throughout the weekends of September, every year.It provides free access to sites of historic, cultural or community interest, increasing public appreciation and enjoyment of Scotland#s built heritage.The event is co-ordinated by the Scottish Civic Trust, and supported by Historic Environment Scotland.Last year, Orkney had two places participating in Orkney for Doors Open Days — the Fossil centre, and the Storytelling Centre. This year Orkney boasts seven venues — some of which are participating for the first time,As far as local people are concerned, Doors Open Days is about getting into buildings for free and seeing things that you don#t often see. If buildings are usually charging an entrance fee they can take part by offering to open for free,The event benefits the organisations or venues by attracting more visitors. It helps them by becoming more involved in the community, as a volunteer or a visitor, and enhancing appreciation of local architecture and local heritage.The seven venues taking part in Orkney all have free entry. For their opening times see the Orkney Doors Open Day or visit the main Doors Open Day website. The local venues are:• The Stromness Museum• Fossil and Heritage Museum, Burray• Deerness Distillery• Orkney Museum, in Kirkwall• Radio Orkney, in Kirkwall• Kirkwall East Church• The Orkney Wireless Museumcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: focus on foil urges oic waste services
story: This Recycling Week, Orkney Islands Council is running a mini-campaign encouraging residents to recycle even more foil trays and household foil.The campaign builds on the Metal Matters initiative launched in , which the local authority has reported saw an impressive increase in the amount of metals being recycled by locals — by  per cent at recycling centres and almost  per cent at the kerbside.Metal Matters was run in conjunction with not-for-profit organisation Alupro who work to fulfil the aluminium packaging industry’s obligation to meet aluminium recycling targets, and led to OIC being selected as a finalist in this year#s MRW National Recycling Awards in the #campaign of the year# category for campaigns under £k.Recycling Week is a national campaign which, this year, runs between September  and .Councillor Graham Sinclair is chairman of the committee responsible for waste services in the county — the council#s Development and Infrastructure Committee. He said: #We want to thank our residents for doing a great job in increasing the amount of metals they recycle at the kerbside.#However, we want to take that even further now by focusing on foil. I was amazed to learn that an average household can expect to use  foil trays and  metres of foil wrap each year.#The good news is that recycling a tonne of aluminium saves nine tonnes of C emissions and four tonnes of bauxite, the raw material from which aluminium is made. And aluminium can be recycled indefinitely.“So it’s clear that each household converted to foil recycling really does make a dference environmentally. The council also gets a goodfor metals recycling, which helps offset the costs of all our waste disposal activities in Orkney.“But we know from speaking to the public that some people are unaware they can recycle foil in Orkney, or aren’t aware of the benefits. That’s why, with Alupro’s help again, we’ll be highlighting foil recycling during Recycling Week and beyond.”As part of awareness-raising, the council will be installing banners provided by Alupro at recycling centres and other public places around Orkney.OIC’s waste team are also featuring facts and figures about foil recycling on the EcoActive Facebook page, and carrying out visits to schools over Recycling Week.In Orkney, householders can put aluminium foil and foil trays in the metal recycling banks at one of the council’s Household Waste Recycling Centres , or into their recycling bin. The advice is to just rinse off food residue and put in your recycling binalongside other metals you can recycle such as food and drink cans and tins, and metal lids and tops from jars and bottles.For smaller pieces of foilit#s best to make a larger ball of foilby scrunching pieces together # it will prevent smaller pieces falling through machinery during the recycling process.For more information about waste and recycling visit the council#s website or email recycling@orkney.gov.uk .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: hoolan wind projects win government contracts
story: Orkney is to become part of a #green energy powerhouse#, said the UK Government, this morning, Friday, as they awarded contracts to two controversial wind farms in the county.Projects at Costa Head in Evie and Hesta Head in South Ronaldsay, developed by Hoolan Energy, have been named as part of a package of  wind farms to win #contracts for dference# — which allow the companies to sell energy at lower prices.The scheme is the government’s main mechanism for supporting new renewable electricity generation project. Successful generators still sell the electricity they produce on the wholesale market but receive a #top-up# payment over the course of the -year contract.Changes made to rules which had forbidden all onshore wind projects from competing in the electricity market in  meant projects in the Western Isles, Shetland and Orkney were able to compete.Prime Minister Boris Johnson said: “The UK is leading the way in the fight against climate change, and it’s great news that millions more homes will be powered by clean energy at record low prices.“Seizing the opportunities of clean energy not only helps to protect our planet, but will also back businesses and boost jobs across the UK.”Though they may have won favour with the government, Hoolan#s two Orkney projects have previously been met with protest from the public and rejection by councillors. More than  protestors took to School Place, last September, when the projects appeared before the OIC planning committee. Though there were no statutory objections to either project, there were  letters of objection and  of support for the Costa project. The Hesta Project, meanwhile, received a total of  objections and nine letters of support.Though councillors elected to reject the wind farms, this decision was later overturned by the Scottish Government. This sparked criticism from former planning chairman, Councillor Owen Tierney, who accused the government of #lacking faith# in the local planning system.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: hygrogen plane tests set for orkney
story: A project which could see the entire aviation industry in Orkney decarbonised has been given huge financial backing.The HyFlyer project aims to decarbonise medium range small passenger aircraft by demonstrating hydrogen fuel cell powertrain technology.It is a project which presents signicant opportunities in Orkney since all flights from Kirkwall could potentially be serviced by this new technology.The project has been awarded £. million of UK Government funding and will culminate in a  nautical mile demonstration flight out of Orkney by .Orkney Islands Council leader James Stockan said: “In Orkney we are seeking to be clean, green islands.#Transport is our biggest decarbonisation challenge, with our remote and rural setting placing our islanders in the position of producing a signicant carbon footprint.“Initiatives like this are presenting us with opportunities to reduce this carbon footprint and support Orkney Islands Council’s climate emergency declaration. I look forward to the project progressing.”Led by ZeroAvia, developers of hydrogen fuel cell powertrain solutions, HyFlyer will demonstrate a phased approach from battery power to hydrogen power, integrating the new technology aboard a Piper M-class six-seater aircraft which will perform test flights out of Cranfield and Orkney.Project partners Intelligent Energy will optimise its high power fuel cell technology for application in aviation while EMEC Hydrogen, producers of green hydrogen from renewable energy, will supply the hydrogen required for flight tests and develop a mobile refuelling  compatible with the plane.The HyFlyer project will see conventional piston engines in propeller aircraft replaced by electric motors, hydrogen fuel cells and gas storage.If all goes well, ZeroAvia, based in Calornia, are aiming to supply the technology to commercial manufacturers by .Following this demonstration, the next goal then is to power an aircraft, carrying up to  passengers, to travel  miles.According to the Air Transport Action Group, aviation is responsible for  per cent of CO emissions from all transport sources and is one of the fastest growing sources of global emissions.Val Mtakhov, founder and CEO of ZeroAvia, said: “The substantial backing provided by the UK Government underlines the potential that hydrogen holds as a fuel source for commercial aviation and provides signicant validation of ZeroAvia’s approach to zero emission flight.“Our project goal of  NM is equivalent to the distance from London to Edinburgh and will prove that zero emission aviation, powered by hydrogen, can play a key role within the UK and other countries’ transport strategies — enabling net zero targets to be met and improving productivity and regional prosperity.”Richard Ainsworth, Hydrogen Project Specialist at EMEC Hydrogen, said: “HyFlyer is another key step in Orkney’s aim to decarbonise leline transport services for islanded communities.#Hydrogen has the potential to help meet our emission commitments where electrons and batteries can’t.#This project sees us one step closer to meeting our fuel and energy needs from abundant local renewable energy resources using green hydrogen.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: newsLoganair reassure Thomas Cook passengersSeptember ,  at : amLoganair has moved to reassure customers who have holidays booked with its interline partner Thomas Cook, which went out of business, today, Monday.According to the airline, these customers will be able to re-book on a Loganair flight connecting to any rearranged element of a holiday where seats are available. Any change fee and dference in fare that would normally apply on the same route will be waived.Loganair managing director Jonathan Hinkles said: “We’re saddened to hear of the closure of Thomas Cook, and thoughts are with its dedicated staff who are at risk of redundancy.#We recognise too that many Loganair customers will have holiday and travel plans made with Thomas Cook which will now need to be re-arranged, and we’ll do what we can to help.”Customers who have a booking to connect to a Thomas Cook flight or holiday, are asked to:If there is a need to fly on a dferent route to meet re-arranged holiday plans, Loganair says it will again waive change fees. However, there may be a small charge to reflect the dference in fare between the original route and the new route booked, based on exactly the same ticket and fare type.The company has said that customers who decide to delay their holiday can put their Loganair flights on hold for up to six months. This facility to make changes to a Loganair booking will be available for until October , giving time to re-arrange travel plans.The Civil Aviation Authorityhas set up a special website at www.thomascook.caa to provide information and guidance to customers on the ious aspects of ATOL claims, repatriation and refunds.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
